item.title: BOJ Unveils Bold Bid to End Deflation
item.description: The Bank of Japan's new leaders delivered on their pledge to radically overhaul the bank's monetary-policy program, unveiling a new easing push so aggressive it surprised markets.

item.title: Draghi Hints at Rate Cuts
item.description: Mario Draghi signaled that the ECB is reluctant to take innovative measures to revive output and employment, but opened the door to an interest-rate cut if the euro zone's flagging growth prospects fail to improve.

item.title: North Korea Moves Missile
item.description: North Korea has moved an intermediate-range missile to its east coast, likely for a test-firing or drill, South Korea's defense minister said Thursday, as tensions on the peninsula remained high.

item.title: Australia's Gillard Leading Delegation to China
item.description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard will lead a senior Australian delegation to China, at a time when the resource-rich nation is increasingly dependent on its fast-growing partner.

item.title: Iran Pushes Back on Nuclear Demands
item.description: Negotiators are looking for a substantive response from Iran that signals it is willing to allay concerns about its nuclear ambitions, as talks resume here on Friday—though Iranian officials tried to deflect that pressure on Thursday.

item.title: Death Toll From Argentine Floods Rises
item.description: The death toll from flooding in La Plata and Buenos Aires rose to at least 55 people as the authorities started to wind down rescue efforts to focus on providing food and shelter to thousands of people left homeless by the disaster.

item.title: China Bird Flu Deaths Rise to Five
item.description: A middle-aged man who transported poultry for a living and another unidentified person have died from a new strain of bird flu, bringing the death toll to five among 14 confirmed cases in China.

item.title: Central African Republic Rebels to Plan Elections
item.description: Rebels who drove out the president in the Central African Republic said they would heed calls from regional leaders to form a transitional government, as South Africa continued to withdraw its few remaining troops from the country.

item.title: As India Party Tries to Sway Gandhi to Run, He Demurs
item.description: Rahul Gandhi, who has the most recognizable surname in Indian politics, gave a rare major speech on Thursday that the party hoped would bring him closer to becoming his party's candidate for prime minister.

item.title: Asean: Nations Can Avoid Overheating
item.description: Southeast Asian finance ministers said they were monitoring the risks from capital flows but expressed confidence that Asean countries can prevent their economies from overheating.

item.title: Asia to Study Promoting Infrastructure Bonds
item.description: Asian countries will study how to promote infrastructure bonds, as a means of channeling funds from within the region into much-needed investment in the sector.

item.title: Syria Rebels Seek Europe, Mideast Aid
item.description: Syria's main rebel command is touring Middle East capitals this week and plans to meet British officials soon to outline specific needs for arms and logistics support as it plans to amplify the fight in Damascus.

item.title: Malaysia Prime Minister Faces Fresh Elections
item.description: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak dissolved parliament, paving the way for an election that analysts say he must win comfortably to avoid being unseated by his own party.

item.title: Canada Widens Terrorism Inquiry
item.description: Canadian authorities are investigating a man from London, Ontario, they say associated with two men from there who died in January, allegedly as part of the team of terrorists who attacked an Algerian gas plant.

item.title: Spanish Princess Named Suspect in Case
item.description: A judge named the youngest daughter of Spanish King Juan Carlos as a suspect in a criminal case relating to her husband's alleged influence-peddling and tax evasion.

item.title: Uganda Suspends Its Hunt for Kony
item.description: Ugandan troops have suspended their search for fugitive warlord Joseph Kony in the jungles of the Central African Republic, fueling fears that the country could descend into deeper disorder.

item.title: Scientists Find Hint of Dark Matter
item.description: A space experiment may have identified the building block of dark matter, the mysterious stuff that's said to pervade a quarter of the universe and yet neither emits nor absorbs light.

item.title: Potential Blueprint for AIDS Vaccine
item.description: Researchers said Wednesday they have mapped an "arms race" in the human body between the AIDS virus and powerful antibodies that fight it off—the latest advance in the pursuit of a vaccine.

item.title: Officials Call for Bold BOJ Easing
item.description: With the Bank of Japan now in a potentially historic policy meeting under new leadership, government officials said Wednesday it should act without worrying about the financial risks of buying longer-term assets.

item.title: Doubts Cast on Chinese Exports
item.description: A discrepancy between China's export data and Hong Kong import numbers has raised doubts about what appeared to be booming overseas demand for Chinese goods, amid uncertainty about the strength of the recovery in the world's second largest economy.

item.title: Mandela's Health Improves
item.description: Nelson Mandela remains hospitalized but his health is improving, South Africa's presidency said, a week after he was admitted with pneumonia.

item.title: Fire Engulfs Luxury Tower in Chechnya
item.description: A luxury high-rise building at the center of a new complex in Chechnya's capital where French actor Gerard Depardieu was given a five-room apartment caught fire Wednesday sending smoke billowing over much of the city.

item.title: India PM: Pessimism Over Economy Unwarranted
item.description: India needs speedy measures to restore economic growth to the 8% levels seen over the past decade, but the pessimism over the current slowdown is unwarranted as it is cyclical and temporary, the prime minister said.

item.title: Weigh More, Pay More on Samoa Air
item.description: A tiny South Pacific airline is charging passengers based on their weight, at a time when other carriers have only ventured to seek payment for luggage and meals.

item.title: As U.S. Departs, Afghan Business Dries Up
item.description: With U.S. military involvement in the nation winding down, Afghan companies that sprang up to serve the foreigners are struggling to survive an uncertain time.

item.title: Boxing Match Fires Up China
item.description: Saturday's boxing match in Macau featuring Zou Shiming, China's two-time Olympic gold medalist, is expected to be a huge television event that could further the sport in Asia

item.title: Singapore Charges Soccer Refs With Corruption
item.description: Singapore brought corruption charges against three Lebanese soccer referees alleged to have taken sexual favors ahead of a game they were due to officiate, the latest match-fixing scandal to hit this Southeast Asian financial center.

item.title: Hungary Looks to Boost Lending
item.description: Hungary's central bank ventured into unconventional territory Thursday, saying it plans to offer interest-free money for loans to small and midsize businesses and help them convert burdensome foreign-currency loans into local forints in an effort to boost the economy.

item.title: Poor Data as ECB Holds Rates
item.description: Activity in the euro zone's private sector fell at a sharper pace in March, leaving the bloc on course for its sixth straight quarter of contraction.

item.title: Cyprus Takes Steps to Secure Aid
item.description: Cyprus will limit first-class travel for senior officials, make it easier for banks to seize a person's home, and cut Easter bonuses to pensioners in exchange for a multibillion-euro bailout from its euro-zone peers and the International Monetary Fund.

item.title: Big Investors Rethink Rosy Outlook on Euro-Zone Debt
item.description: Several large institutional investors are starting to question the European Central Bank's ability to stay true to its pledge last July to "do whatever it takes" to support the euro zone.

item.title: Paris Saint-Germain Dares to Dream Big
item.description: Onetime French also-ran aims for Champions League dominance—but Barcelona has other ideas.

item.title: Winning on the Track Takes More Than a Horse
item.description: In Hong Kong, where horse racing is a passion, Matthew Chadwick is one of the winningest jockeys. Being as good as he is, he says, involves long hours and a lot of discipline and personal sacrifice.

item.title: 'Finnegans Wake' Is Greek to Many; Now Imagine It in Chinese
item.description: A Chinese translation of the James Joyce novel, in the works for years, has become a modest but clear hit in China.

item.title: Channeling Mrs. Thatcher in Tokyo, Seoul
item.description: Margaret Thatcher's ideas are enjoying a renaissance in Asia, where the new leaders of Japan and South Korea embrace the Cold War-era British leader as a role model.

item.title: Photos of the Day: April 3
item.description: In today's pictures, a tuberculosis patient rests in an Indonesian hospital, a soldier evacuates a flooding victim in Argentina, Connecticut lawmakers debate gun control, and more.

item.title: Author Ruth Prawer Jhabvala Dies at 85
item.description: Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, who wrote screenplays for Merchant Ivory and was a prolific novelist, won Oscars for her adaptations of "Howards End" and "A Room With a View."

item.title: England's Best Team...in Spain
item.description: For the first time in 17 years, an English team wouldn't be represented in the quarterfinals of Europe's most prestigious club competition. But Málaga leaves plenty of intrigue for a few thousand Brits.

item.title: Photos of the Day: April 2
item.description: In today's pictures, Palestinian protesters take cover in the West Bank, a man floats in a dinghy through the streets of Buenos Aires, militia members help farmers pick tea in China, and more.

item.title: A 200-Year-Old Spat Over Tortoise Name Has a Winner
item.description: An ugly 200-year-old spat over the Latin name for an Indian Ocean tortoise finally has a winner.
